key_points: The _curses_panel is built on top of the curses library, offering an easier and more flexible way to create text-based GUIs compared to traditional curses methods.
It provides a panel class for creating multi-window applications with easy navigation between them.
Supports various widgets like buttons, textboxes, progress bars, and more to build custom interfaces.
Includes layout managers for arranging and managing the positioning of panels and widgets within the application.
The module supports Unicode characters and colorful text output for enhanced visual appeal.
It has a consistent API across various platforms, making it platform-independent.

code_examples.code:
```
import curses
from curses.panel import new_panel,
                           derivative_panel,
                           grid_layout,
                           FormView,
                           TextBox,
                           ButtonPanel

stdscr = curses.initscr()
my_grid = grid_layout(2, 3)

textbox1 = TextBox(my_grid, 0, 0) 
textbox1.edit("Enter some text here!")

button_panel = ButtonPanel(my_grid, 2, 0)
button_panel.add_button("Save", save_data)
button_panel.add_default("Cancel", curses.wrapper(curses.endwin))

main_panel = derivatives.VBox([textbox1, button_panel])
main_panel.set(new_panel(my_grid))

curses.centered_windows(stdscr, main_panel, unpack=True)
```

version_notes: Improvements and additional features may be added with future releases.
caveats: While offering more flexibility, the _curses_panel module can have a steeper learning curve compared to traditional curses methods.
The performance might not be as good as other GUI libraries like Tkinter or PyQt when it comes to handling heavy graphical applications.
Some platform-specific limitations may apply, but the _curses_panel module aims to provide consistent functionality across platforms.
